newsitem.title: USA: ALPINE SKIING-ALPHAND NEAR-CERTAIN WINNER OF WORLD CUP.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-ALPHAND NEAR-CERTAIN WINNER OF WORLD CUP.

text.p: Norway's Finn Christian Jagge was fastest in the first leg of the men's slalom on Sunday but his compatriot Kjetil Andre Aamodt lagged way behind to make France's Luc Alphand a virtual certainty for the overall Alpine skiing World Cup title.

Aamodt, needing to finish first or second in the climactic race of the World Cup season, stood 16th after the first leg, 1.71 seconds off the pace. Only an epidemic of crashes in the final run would give him a chance to overtake Alphand.
Jagge, skiing from the fourth start position, knifed through the 62-gate course on Vail Mountain in 50.35 seconds, 0.72 of a second ahead of slalom standings leader Thomas Sykora of Austria.
Victory by Jagge, who began the race ranked sixth in the slalom standings, could lift him to third place.
One-hundredth of a second slower than Sykora was his compatriot Thomas Stangassinger, who entered the race 76 points behind Sykora in the standings.
Italian star Alberto Tomba, who has struggled with injuries this season, was fifth fastest behind Tom Stiansen of Norway.
Frenchman Sebastien Amiez, third in the standings going into the race, missed a gate near the top and came back on to finish the course more than six seconds off the pace.
Tomba, 0.89 of a second slower than Jagge, would need to win the race to overtake Amiez in the season standings.
